ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: One short book a week to read. Very manageable. I'd say half the books are great, the other half pretty bad. We talk about general themes of Brazil in modernity and Prof. Jackson does a great job intertwining history lessons into the literature that we read. Essays are also manageable, but make sure you speak clearly in them, he prefers good writing to good ideas. This class will be a snore if you don't read the books and do some background googling on themes you found interesting while reading the novels. I would recommend.
It was great, interesting, laid-back. Fun!

I would definitely recommend this class because it introduces you to Brazilian Literature in general. More specifically it introduces you to several themes"Internationalization of Brazilian Literature post 1985", "desire", "love", "sex", "social criticism" etc.
I wouldn't really recommend this class, as the novels chosen are sometimes surprisingly poorly written, and the discussions are not led well.
